dialog.text: Why do tiny things make me explode like I've been hit by a truck? I don't understand it.
dialog.instructions: voice: young, honest, urgent; tone: confused and frustrated; pace: quick; emotional range: raw curiosity

dialog.text: Because your pain has a voice that sometimes yells to be heard. A trigger is that voice, not the finger pointing at someone else.
dialog.instructions: voice: deep, calm; tone: soothing and clear; pace: measured; emotional range: compassionate; impression: wise shadow-teacher

dialog.text: But they said something small — how does that become a war inside me?
dialog.instructions: voice: defensive, hurt; tone: incredulous; pace: faster; emotional range: wounded

dialog.text: The words were small. The echo inside you is old. Your shadow carries the echoes of every time you felt unseen, unsafe, or unlovable.
dialog.instructions: voice: gentle; tone: explanatory; pace: slow; emotional range: tender

dialog.text: Shadow? So it's... inside me? A part of me that's broken?
dialog.instructions: voice: tentative, whispering; tone: uncertain; pace: slow; emotional range: vulnerable

dialog.text: Yes. Not a monster to fight, but a child to meet. It protected you with a script that once saved you — now it repeats the same scene until it's witnessed.
dialog.instructions: voice: warm, steady; tone: reassuring; pace: calm; emotional range: compassionate

dialog.text: It just screams. I want to shut it down or run away. How do I even meet a screaming part?
dialog.instructions: voice: anxious; tone: pleading; pace: quick; emotional range: overwhelmed

dialog.text: Pause. Breathe. Name the feeling — anger, shame, fear. Ask it one question: 'What are you afraid will happen if I stop protecting us?'. Listen like you would to a scared child.
dialog.instructions: voice: instructional, calm; tone: practical and gentle; pace: slow; emotional range: encouraging

dialog.text: (softly) Okay... I breathed. I told it to say its fear. It said it feels abandoned — like the little me was left behind.
dialog.instructions: voice: softened, breaking; tone: intimate; pace: slower; emotional range: tender and relieved

dialog.text: That is the truth. Naming it takes the power out of the story. Truth, held without shame, stops running in circles. The shadow needs acknowledgement, not exile.
dialog.instructions: voice: steady, warm; tone: validating; pace: measured; emotional range: hopeful

dialog.text: So triggers are actually... teachers? They point to something I haven't healed?
dialog.instructions: voice: surprised, hopeful; tone: lightening; pace: moderate; emotional range: curious

dialog.text: Exactly. Each trigger is a doorway. Inner work is walking through, seeing the wound, and choosing a new way to respond. You don't erase the past — you befriend it.
dialog.instructions: voice: confident, peaceful; tone: empowering; pace: steady; emotional range: uplifting

dialog.text: It feels smaller when I meet it. Not gone, but less ruling my day. Is that freedom?
dialog.instructions: voice: reflective, quietly joyful; tone: tentative hope; pace: gentle; emotional range: relieved

dialog.text: Freedom is learning to choose your response instead of reacting on replay. The shadow will visit again — each time you meet it, you graduate a little closer to yourself.
dialog.instructions: voice: warm, firm; tone: encouraging; pace: steady; emotional range: resolute

dialog.text: I'll keep practicing. I'll try listening before I lash out.
dialog.instructions: voice: determined, soft; tone: committed; pace: steady; emotional range: hopeful

dialog.text: Small practice: tonight, notice one recurring trigger. Name the emotion for three breaths. Leave one sentence about what you heard in the comments — not to be fixed, but to be witnessed. Your truth matters.
dialog.instructions: voice: inviting, calm; tone: gentle call to action; pace: clear; emotional range: encouraging
